content: Don't forget, the Red Cross are the guys who send your family messages. They helped Mike Durant when he was grievously injured and captured in Mogadishu. I am better than the terrorists. Having actually fought in Iraq, I am proud to say my conduct and the conduct of my fellow soldiers was in line with the Geneva Conventions (and that includes how we handled people we detained). A sure sign that you are on a slippery slope is when you start splitting hairs over torture. The North Vietnamese tortured our POW's in numerous ways and some of that included extreme isolation. If you don't think isolation, extreme hot and cold temperatures, and water boarding are torture; you probably just don't want to think about those things too deeply. Torture is more than pulling fingernails, prolonged mental torture is just as damaging. If these things truly are "little more than frat house hazing", then what purpose did they actually serve? You cannot split hairs over the law. It is written in black and white. In basic training I was taught that we didn't torture people because it was against everything we stood for, and because it invited reprisals. Now I know that terrorists don't respect the law. But we do, and some day, a future enemy is going to use Gitmo and Abu Ghraib as justification for their own torture programs. People often say "Terrorists are evil, they don't respect the laws, so why should we?" Well if you believe that, the flipside is also true. We can't very well hold anyone accountable for the mistreatment of our POW's if we don't treat enemy POW's any better.
